{{good article}} [[File:Fields of Iaru (KV11).jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|[[Agriculture]], here showing [[cereal]] [[harvest]]ing and [[plough]]ing using [[domesticated]] [[cattle]], has been critical to human [[civilisation]] since the time of [[Ancient Egypt]]. [[Book of the Dead]], spell 110: Fields of Iaru. Scene from tomb of [[Ramses III]] (1186–1155 BC)]]
'''Human uses of living things''', including [[human uses of animals|animals]]<ref>{{cite web |title=The Purpose of Humanimalia |url=https://www.depauw.edu/humanimalia/humanimalifesto.html |publisher=De Pauw University |accessdate=12 September 2018 |quote=animal/human interfaces have been a neglected area of research, given the ubiquity of animals in human culture and history, and the dramatic change in our material relationships since the rise of agribusiness farming and pharmacological research, genetic experimentation, and the erosion of animal habitats.}}</ref> [[human uses of plants|plants]],<ref name="Shoemaker pp. 3–7">{{cite journal | last=Shoemaker | first=Candice A. | title=Plants and Human Culture | journal=Journal of Home & Consumer Horticulture | volume=1 | issue=2–3 | date=1994-08-02 | doi=10.1300/j280v01n02_02 | pages=3–7}}</ref> [[human interactions with fungi|fungi]], and [[human interactions with microbes|microbes]], take many forms, both practical, such as the production of food and clothing, and symbolic, as in art, mythology, and religion. The skills and practices involved are transmitted by human [[culture]] through social [[learning]].<ref name=MacionisGerber2011/>
[[Plants]] provide the greater part of the [[food]] for people and their [[domestic animal]]s: much of human [[culture]] and [[civilisation]] came into being through [[agriculture]]. While a large number of plants have been used for food, a small number of [[staple crop]]s including [[wheat]], [[rice]], and [[maize]] provide most of the food in the world today. In turn, [[animals]] provide much of the [[meat]] eaten by the human population, whether farmed or hunted, and until the arrival of mechanised transport, terrestrial mammals provided a large part of the power used for work and transport. A variety of living things serve as [[model organism|models]] in [[biological research]], such as in [[genetics]], and in [[drug testing]]. Until the 19th century, [[medicinal plant|plants yielded]] most of the [[medicinal drugs]] in common use, as described in the 1st century by [[Dioscorides]]. Plants are the source of many [[psychoactive drug]]s, some such as [[coca]] known to have been used for thousands of years. [[Yeast]], a fungus, has been used to [[fermentation|ferment]] [[cereal]]s such as wheat and barley to make [[bread]] and [[beer]]; other fungi such as ''[[Psilocybe]]'' and [[fly agaric]] mushrooms have been gathered as psychoactive drugs.
Many species of animal are kept as [[pet]]s, the most popular being [[mammals]], especially [[dog]]s and [[cat]]s. Plants are grown for pleasure in gardens and greenhouses, yielding flowers, shade, and decorative foliage; some, such as [[cactus]]es, able to tolerate dry conditions, are grown as [[houseplant]]s.
Animals such as [[horse]]s and [[deer]] are among the earliest subjects of [[art]], being found in the [[Upper Paleolithic]] [[cave painting]]s such as at [[Lascaux]].
Living things further play a wide variety of symbolic roles in literature, film, mythology, and religion. Sometimes a major [[disease]] like [[tuberculosis]], caused by a [[bacterium]], [[Tuberculosis in human culture|plays a role in culture]], in its case being associated for some reason with artistic creativity.
==Context==
[[Culture]] consists of the [[social behaviour]] and [[Norm (social)|norms]] found in [[human]] [[society|societies]] and transmitted through social [[learning]]. [[Cultural universals]] in all human societies include expressive forms like [[art]], [[music]], [[dance]], [[ritual]], [[religion]], and [[technology|technologies]] like [[tool|tool usage]], [[cooking]], [[shelter (building)|shelter]], and [[clothing]]. The concept of [[material culture]] covers physical expressions such as technology, architecture and art, whereas immaterial culture includes principles of [[social organization]], [[mythology]], [[philosophy]], [[literature]], and [[science]].<ref name=MacionisGerber2011>{{cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/sociology/oclc/652430995 |title=Sociology |last=Macionis |first=John J. |last2=Gerber |first2=Linda Marie |date=2011 |publisher=Pearson Prentice Hall |isbn=978-0137001613 |page=53 |accessdate=29 May 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818045455/https://www.worldcat.org/title/sociology/oclc/652430995 |archivedate=18 August 2017 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="Churchman1987">{{cite book |last1=Churchman |first1=David |title=The Educational Role of Zoos: A Synthesis of the Literature (1928-1987) with Annotated Bibliography |date=1987 |publisher=California State University |page=8 |ref=ED289742 |quote=addressing the broad question of the relationship between animals and human culture. The committee argues that zoos should foster awareness of the involvement of animals in literature, music, history, art, medicine, religion, folklore, language, commerce, food, and adornment of the world's culture's, present and past}}</ref> The term "bioculture" has been proposed to cover all the practical uses (but not the symbolic ones) of living things in culture, including agriculture, production of food and clothing, forestry, animal breeding and training, the pet trade, use of living things in science, zoos and aquariums, animal sports, and the raising of game animals for sport hunting.<ref>{{cite book |last=Taylor |first=Paul W. |title=Respect for Nature: A Theory of Environmental Ethics |edition=25th Anniversary |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9TdcnC98eRwC&pg=PA53 |year=2011 |publisher=Princeton University Press |isbn=978-1-4008-3853-0 |pages=53–54}}</ref> [[Anthropology]] has traditionally studied the roles of animals and of plants in human culture in two opposed ways: as physical resources that humans used; and as symbols or concepts through [[totemism]] and [[animism]]. More recently, anthropologists have also seen living things as participants in human social interactions.<ref name="WhiteCandeaLazarRobbins2018">{{cite journal | last=White | first=Thomas | last2=Candea | first2=Matei | last3=Lazar | first3=Sian | last4=Robbins | first4=Joel | last5=Sanchez | first5=Andrew | last6=Stasch | first6=Rupert | editor-last=Stein | editor-first=Felix | editor-last2=Candea | editor-first2=Matei | editor-last3=Diemberger | editor-first3=Hildegard | title=Animals | journal=Cambridge Encyclopedia of Anthropology | date=2018-05-23 | doi=10.29164/18animals}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Editors' Introduction |journal=Cultural Anthropology |date=November 2010 |volume=25 |issue=4 |url=https://culanth.org/issues/18-25-4-november-2010 |accessdate=12 September 2018 |quote=Creatures previously appearing on the margins of anthropology—as part of the landscape, as food for humans, as symbols—have been pressed into the foreground in recent ethnographies. Animals, plants, fungi, and microbes once confined in anthropological accounts to the realm of zoe or 'bare life'—that which is killable—have started to appear alongside humans in the realm of bios, with legibly biographical and political lives.}}</ref><ref name="OgdenHallTanita2013">{{cite journal | last=Ogden | first=Laura A. | last2=Hall | first2=Billy | last3=Tanita | first3=Kimiko | title=Animals, Plants, People, and Things: A Review of Multispecies Ethnography | journal=Environment and Society | volume=4 | issue=1 | date=2013-01-01 | doi=10.3167/ares.2013.040102 | pages=1–24}}</ref> This article describes the roles played by living things in human culture, so defined.
==Practical uses==
===For food and materials=== [[File:KerbauJawa.jpg|thumb|right|Ploughing [[rice]] fields with [[water buffalo]] in [[Indonesia]]]] {{main|Agriculture|Fishing|Forestry}}
The human population exploits and depends on a large number of animal and plant species for [[food]], mainly through [[agriculture]], an essential component of human culture, but also by exploiting wild populations, notably of marine [[fish]].<ref name="Humans and Plants 1998 pp. 335–345">{{cite book | author1=Ksenzhek, Octavian S. | author2=Volkov, Alexander G. | title=Plant Energetics | chapter=Humans and Plants | publisher=Elsevier | year=1998 | isbn=978-0-12-427350-4 | doi=10.1016/b978-012427350-4/50016-9 | pages=335–345}}</ref><ref name=FAOFish>{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/fishery/ |title=Fisheries and Aquaculture |publisher=FAO |accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref><ref name=Economist/> [[Livestock]] animals are raised for meat across the world; they include (2011) around 1.4 billion [[cattle]], 1.2 billion [[sheep]] and 1 billion [[domestic pig]]s.<ref name=Economist>{{Cite journal|title=Graphic detail Charts, maps and infographics. Counting chickens|journal=The Economist|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2011/07/global-livestock-counts|accessdate=23 June 2016|date=27 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Cattle Today |url=http://cattle-today.com/ |title=Breeds of Cattle at CATTLE TODAY |publisher=Cattle-today.com |accessdate=15 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Lukefahr |first1=S.D. |last2=Cheeke |first2=P.R. |title=Rabbit project development strategies in subsistence farming systems |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/U4900T/u4900T0m.htm |publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization]]|accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref>
Plants provide the greater part of food for humans, and for their [[domestic animal]]s. They have [[History of agriculture|played a key role in the history of world civilizations]]. Agriculture includes [[agronomy]] for arable crops, [[horticulture]] for vegetables and fruit, and [[forestry]] for timber.<ref name=NatGeogAgriculture>{{cite web |title=The Development of Agriculture |url=https://genographic.nationalgeographic.com/development-of-agriculture/ |publisher=[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] |accessdate=20 June 2016 |date=2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414142437/https://genographic.nationalgeographic.com/development-of-agriculture/ |archivedate=14 April 2016 |df= }}</ref> About 7,000 species of plant have been used for food, though most of today's food is derived from only 30 species. The major [[staple crop|staples]] include [[cereal]]s such as [[rice]] and [[wheat]], starchy roots and tubers such as [[cassava]] and [[potato]], and [[legume]]s such as [[peas]] and [[bean]]s. [[Vegetable oil]]s such as [[olive oil]] provide [[lipids]], while [[fruit]] and [[vegetable]]s contribute [[vitamin]]s and minerals to the diet.<ref>{{cite web |title=Food and drink |url=http://www.kew.org/science-conservation/plants-fungi/food-drink |publisher=[[Kew Gardens]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref>
Plants grown as [[industrial crop]]s are the source of a wide range of products used in manufacturing, sometimes so intensively as to risk harm to the environment.<ref>{{cite web |title=Industrial Crop Production |url=http://www.sustainabletable.org/804/industrial-crop-production |publisher=Grace Communications Foundation |accessdate=20 June 2016|date=2016}}</ref> Nonfood products include [[essential oil]]s, [[natural dye]]s, pigments, waxes, [[resin]]s, [[tannin]]s, alkaloids, amber and [[Cork material|cork]]. Products derived from plants include soaps, shampoos, perfumes, cosmetics, paint, varnish, turpentine, rubber, [[latex]], lubricants, linoleum, plastics, inks, and [[Gum (botany)|gums]]. Renewable fuels from plants include [[firewood]], [[peat]] and other [[biofuel]]s.<ref>{{cite web |title=INDUSTRIAL CROPS AND PRODUCTS An International Journal |url=https://www.elsevier.com/journals/industrial-crops-and-products/0926-6690?generatepdf=true |publisher=Elsevier |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="CruzDierig2014">{{cite book |last1=Cruz |first1=Von Mark V. |last2=Dierig |first2=David A. |title=Industrial Crops: Breeding for BioEnergy and Bioproducts |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iIFxBQAAQBAJ&pg=PR9 |year=2014 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-1-4939-1447-0 |pages=9 and passim}}</ref> The [[fossil fuel]]s [[coal]], [[petroleum]] and [[natural gas]] are derived from the remains of aquatic organisms including [[phytoplankton]] in [[geological time]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sato |first1=Motoaki |title=Thermochemistry of the formation of fossil fuels |work=Fluid-Mineral Interactions: A Tribute to H. P. Eugster, Special Publication No.2 |date=1990 |url=http://www.geochemsoc.org/files/6214/1261/1770/SP-2_271-284_Sato.pdf |publisher=The Geochemical Society}}</ref> Structural resources and fibres from plants are used to construct dwellings and to manufacture clothing. [[Wood]] is used not only for buildings, boats, and furniture, but also for smaller items such as [[musical instrument]]s and sports equipment. Wood is [[Pulp (paper)|pulped]] to make paper and cardboard.<ref>{{cite book |title=Handbook of pulp |volume=1 |editor1-last=Sixta |editor1-first=Herbert |year=2006 |publisher=Wiley-VCH |location=Winheim, Germany |isbn=978-3-527-30997-9 |page=9}}</ref> Cloth is often made from [[cotton]], [[flax]], [[ramie]] or synthetic fibres such as [[rayon]] and [[acetate]] derived from plant [[cellulose]]. [[Thread (yarn)|Thread]] used to sew cloth likewise comes in large part from cotton.<ref>{{cite web |title=Natural fibres |url=http://www.naturalfibres2009.org/en/fibres/|website=Discover Natural Fibres |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> Plants are a primary source of basic [[chemicals]], both for their medicinal and physiological effects, and for the industrial synthesis of a vast array of organic chemicals.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chemicals from Plants|publisher=Cambridge University Botanic Garden}} Note that the details of each plant and the chemicals it yields are described in the linked subpages.</ref>
[[Textiles]] are made from both animal fibres, including [[wool]] and [[silk]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Animals Used for Clothing|url=http://www.peta.org/issues/animals-used-for-clothing/|publisher=PETA|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ancient fabrics, high-tech geotextiles|url=http://www.naturalfibres2009.org/en/fibres/|publisher=Natural Fibres|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> and plant fibres, including [[cotton]] and [[flax]]. Dyestuffs too are made both from animals, including [[carmine]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/v8879e/v8879e09.htm |title=Cochineal and Carmine |work=Major colourants and dyestuffs, mainly produced in horticultural systems |publisher=FAO |accessdate=June 16, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/ForIndustry/ColorAdditives/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/ucm153038.htm |title=Guidance for Industry: Cochineal Extract and Carmine |publisher=FDA |accessdate=6 July 2016}}</ref> from the bodies of insects, and from plants, including [[indigo]], [madder], and [[lichen]]s.
===For work and transport=== {{main article|Working animal|Pack animal}}
[[Working animal|Working domestic animals]] including cattle, horses, yaks, camels, and elephants have been used for work and transport from the origins of agriculture, their numbers declining with the arrival of mechanised transport and agricultural machinery. In 2004 they still provided some 80% of the power for the mainly small farms in the third world, and some 20% of the world's transport, again mainly in rural areas. In mountainous regions unsuitable for wheeled vehicles, [[pack animal]]s continue to transport goods.<ref name="Pond2004">{{cite book |last=Pond |first=Wilson G. |title=Encyclopedia of Animal Science |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1SQl7Ao3mHoC&pg=PA248 |year=2004 |publisher=CRC Press |isbn=978-0-8247-5496-9 |pages=248–250}}</ref>
===In science=== [[File:Lightmatter lab mice.jpg|thumb|Laboratory [[House mouse|mice]] are widely used in medical research.]] [[Biology]] studies the whole range of living things.
Animals such as the fruit fly ''[[Drosophila melanogaster]]'', the [[zebrafish]], the [[chicken]] and the [[house mouse]], serve a major role in science as [[model organism|experimental models]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Doke|first1=Sonali K.|last2=Dhawale|first2=Shashikant C.|title=Alternatives to animal testing: A review|journal=Saudi Pharmaceutical Journal|date=July 2015|volume=23|issue=3|pages=223–229|doi=10.1016/j.jsps.2013.11.002|pmid=26106269|pmc=4475840|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1319016413001096}}</ref> both in fundamental [[biology|biological]] research, such as in [[genetics]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Genetics Research |url=http://www.aht.org.uk/cms-display/genetics.html |publisher=Animal Health Trust |accessdate=24 June 2016}}</ref> and in the development of new medicines, which must be tested exhaustively to demonstrate their safety.<ref>{{cite web |title=Drug Development |url=http://www.animalresearch.info/en/drug-development/ |publisher=Animal Research.info |accessdate=24 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Animal Experimentation|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ethics/animals/using/experiments_1.shtml|publisher=BBC|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> Millions of mammals, especially mice and rats, are used in [[animal testing|experiments]] each year.<ref name="EUstatistics2013">{{cite web |title=EU statistics show decline in animal research numbers |url=http://speakingofresearch.com/2013/12/12/eu-statistics-show-decline-in-animal-research-numbers/ |publisher=Speaking of Research |year=2013 |accessdate=January 24, 2016}}</ref> [[knockout mouse|Knockout mice]] are used to help discover the functions of genes.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Helen R. Pilcher |url=http://www.nature.com/news/1998/030512/full/news030512-17.html |title=It's a knockout |publisher=Nature |date=2003 |accessdate=24 June 2016|doi=10.1038/news030512-17}}</ref><ref>[http://molpharm.wisc.edu/Faculty/fac_pages/gould/Pub12754522.pdf Y Zan et al., Production of knockout rats using ENU mutagenesis and a yeast-based screening assay, Nat. Biotechnol. (2003).]{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611201320/http://molpharm.wisc.edu/Faculty/fac_pages/gould/Pub12754522.pdf |date=June 11, 2010 }}</ref>
Basic biological research has often been done with plants. In [[genetics]], the breeding of pea plants allowed [[Gregor Mendel]] to derive the basic laws governing inheritance,<ref>{{cite web |title=Mendel's Paper in English |url=http://www.mendelweb.org/Mendel.html |first=Roger B. |last=Blumberg}}</ref> and examination of [[chromosome]]s in maize allowed [[Barbara McClintock]] to demonstrate their connection to inherited traits.<ref>{{cite web|title=BARBARA McCLINTOCK:A Brief Biographical Sketch |url=http://library.cshl.edu/sp/scientists/barbara_mcclintock/mcclintock_biography.html |publisher=WebCite |accessdate=21 June 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/615y4NCQG?url=http://library.cshl.edu/archives/archives/bmcbio.htm |archivedate=21 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> The plant ''[[Arabidopsis thaliana]]'' is used in laboratories as a [[model organism]] to understand how [[gene]]s control the growth and development of plant structures.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Arabidopsis|url=http://www.arabidopsis.org/portals/education/aboutarabidopsis.jsp|publisher=TAIR|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> Space stations or space colonies may one day rely on plants for [[Controlled Ecological Life Support System|life support]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Engineering Life|url=http://settlement.arc.nasa.gov/Contest/Results/96/winner/seis.html|publisher=[[NASA]]|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref>
===For medicines and drugs=== [[File:NaplesDioscuridesMandrake.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Mandrake (plant)|Mandrake]] in [[Dioscorides]]'s ''[[De Materia Medica]]'', one of hundreds of [[medicinal plants]] used since [[classical antiquity]]]] {{further|Medicinal plants}}
[[Vaccine]]s have been made using animals since their discovery by [[Edward Jenner]] in the 18th century. He noted that inoculation with live [[cowpox]] afforded protection against the more dangerous [[smallpox]]. In the 19th century, [[Louis Pasteur]] developed an attenuated (weakened) vaccine for [[rabies]]. In the 20th century, vaccines for the viral diseases [[mumps]] and [[polio]] were developed using animal cells grown [[in vitro]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Vaccines and animal cell technology |url=http://www.actip.org/library/vaccines-and-animal-cell-technology/ |publisher=Animal Cell Technology Industrial Platform |accessdate=9 July 2016}}</ref>
An increasing variety of [[medicinal drug]]s are based on [[toxin]]s and other molecules of animal origin. The cancer drug [[Yondelis]] was isolated from the [[tunicate]] ''[[Ecteinascidia turbinata]]''. One of dozens of toxins made by the deadly cone snail ''[[Conus geographus]]'' is used as [[Prialt]] in pain relief.<ref>{{cite web |title=Medicines by Design |url=https://publications.nigms.nih.gov/medbydesign/chapter3.html |publisher=National Institute of Health |accessdate=9 July 2016}}</ref>
Since [[classical antiquity|classical times]] and possibly much earlier, hundreds of species of plants have provided drugs to treat a wide range of conditions. [[Dioscorides]]'s ''[[De Materia Medica]]'', written by 70 AD, listed some 600 [[medicinal plant]]s and around 1000 drugs made from them, including substances known to be effective such as [[aconitum|aconite]], [[aloes]], [[colocynth]], [[colchicum]], [[henbane]], [[opium]] and [[squill]]. The book remained a standard reference for nearly two thousand years, and was the basis of the European [[pharmacopoeia]] until the end of the 19th century.<ref name=Osbaldestonxxi>{{cite book | url=http://www.ibidispress.scriptmania.com/box_widget.html | work=Dioscorides | publisher=Ibidis Press | author=Osbaldeston, Tess Anne (translator) | year=2000 | location=Johannesburg | title=Introduction | pages=xxi–xxvi | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924062658/http://www.ibidispress.scriptmania.com/box_widget.html | archivedate=2014-09-24 | df= }}</ref><ref name="Vos 2010">{{cite journal | author=De Vos, Paula | year=2010 | title=European Materia Medica in Historical Texts: Longevity of a Tradition and Implications for Future Use | journal=Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume=132 | issue=1 | pages=28–47 | doi=10.1016/j.jep.2010.05.035 | pmid=20561577 | pmc=2956839}}</ref>
Also since the earliest times, people have exploited some of the many [[psychoactive substance]]s manufactured by plants in religious rituals and for pleasure.<ref name="merlin">{{cite journal | author=Merlin, M.D | title=Archaeological Evidence for the Tradition of Psychoactive Plant Use in the Old World | journal=Economic Botany | volume=57 | issue=3 | pages= 295–323 | doi=10.1663/0013-0001(2003)057[0295:AEFTTO]2.0.CO;2 | year=2003 }}</ref> Among the most widely used throughout history are [[alcohol]], produced by [[fermentation|fermenting]] cereals with [[yeast]] (a fungus),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertlaura/2013/12/26/will-your-retirement-home-have-a-liquor-license/|title=Will Your Retirement Home Have A Liquor License?|date=26 December 2013|work=Forbes}}</ref> [[tobacco]], [[coffee]], [[tea]], [[chocolate]], [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]], [[coca]] (used as leaf for some 8,000 years in Peru,<ref>Early Holocene coca chewing in northern Peru Volume: 84 Number: 326 Page: 939–953</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-11878241 | work=BBC News | title=Coca leaves first chewed 8,000 years ago, says research | date=2 December 2010}}</ref> and in recent times also purified to [[cocaine]]), [[mescaline]] (from a cactus) and [[psilocybin]] (from a fungus).<ref name="bushbook">{{cite book|chapter=CHAPTER 1 Alcohol and Other Drugs|isbn=978-0-7245-3361-9|chapter-url=http://www.nt.gov.au/health/healthdev/health_promotion/bushbook/volume2/chap1/sect1.htm|title=An overview of alcohol and other drug issues|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328060739/http://www.nt.gov.au/health/healthdev/health_promotion/bushbook/volume2/chap1/sect1.htm|archivedate=2015-03-28|df=}}</ref>
===For pleasure=== [[File:Azaleas in a Landscape Isabella Plantation.jpg|thumb|The colourful floral display in the [[Isabella Plantation]], [[Richmond Park]], London attracts many visitors.]]
Both animals and plants are used to provide pleasure, through a range of activities including keeping pets, hunting, fishing, and gardening.
A wide variety of animals are kept as [[pet]]s, from invertebrates such as tarantulas and octopuses, insects including [[praying mantis]]es,<ref>{{cite web|title=Other bugs|url=http://www.keepinginsects.com/cockroaches-locusts-ants/|publisher=Keeping Insects|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> [[reptile]]s such as [[snake]]s and [[chameleon]]s,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kaplan|first1=Melissa|title=So, you think you want a reptile?|url=http://www.anapsid.org/parent.html|publisher=Anapsid.org|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> and [[bird]]s including [[Canary (bird)|canaries]], [[parakeet]]s and [[parrot]]s<ref>{{cite web|title=Pet Birds|url=http://www.humanesociety.org/animals/pet_birds/|publisher=PDSA|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> all finding a place. Mammals are the most popular pets in the Western world, with the most kept species being [[dog]]s, [[cat]]s, and [[rabbit]]s. For example, in America in 2012 there were some 78 million [[dog]]s, 86 million [[cat]]s, and 3.5 million [[rabbit]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shea-online.org/Portals/0/PDFs/Animals%20in%20Healthcare%20Facilities.pdf |title=Animals in Healthcare Facilities |date=2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304102728/http://www.shea-online.org/Portals/0/PDFs/Animals%20in%20Healthcare%20Facilities.pdf |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=The Humane Society of the United States |title=U.S. Pet Ownership Statistics |url=http://www.humanesociety.org/issues/pet_overpopulation/facts/pet_ownership_statistics.html |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=USDA |title=U.S. Rabbit Industry profile |url=http://www.aphis.usda.gov/animal_health/emergingissues/downloads/RabbitReport1.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2013}}</ref> There is a tension between the role of animals as companions to humans, and their existence as [[animal rights|individuals with rights]] of their own.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Role of Animals in Human Society |author=Plous, S. |date=1993 |doi=10.1111/j.1540-4560.1993.tb00906.x |journal=Journal of Social Issues |volume=49 |issue=1 |pages=1–9}}</ref>
Many animals are [[hunting|hunted]] for sport.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hummel |first1=Richard |title=Hunting and Fishing for Sport: Commerce, Controversy, Popular Culture|date=1994|publisher=Popular Press|isbn=978-0-87972-646-1}}</ref> The aquatic animals most often hunted for sport are fish, including many species from large marine predators such as [[shark]]s and [[tuna]]<!--overlink, seems sensible here-->, to freshwater fish such as [[trout]] and [[carp]]<!--overlink, again seems reasonable here-->.<ref>{{cite web |title=The World's Top 100 Game Fish|url=http://www.sportfishingmag.com/top-100-game-fish |publisher=Sport Fishing Magazine|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Fish species for recreational fishing |url=http://www.slovenia.info/?ribe=0 |publisher=Slovenia.info |accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> Birds such as [[partridge]]s, [[pheasant]]s and [[duck]]s, and mammals such as [[deer]] and [[wild boar]], are among the terrestrial [[game (hunting)|game animals]] most often [[hunting|hunted]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Deer Hunting in the United States: An Analysis of Hunter Demographics and Behavior Addendum to the 2001 National Survey of Fishing, Hunting, and Wildlife-Associated Recreation Report 2001-6 |url=http://digitalmedia.fws.gov/cdm/ref/collection/document/id/292 |publisher=Fishery and Wildlife Service (USA) |accessdate=24 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Recreational Hog Hunting Popularity Soaring |url=http://www.grandviewoutdoors.com/big-game-hunting/recreational-hog-hunting-popularity-soaring/ |publisher=Gramd View Outdoors|accessdate=24 June 2016|date=2014-04-05 }}</ref><ref name="NguyenWheatley2015">{{cite book |last1=Nguyen |first1=Jenny |last2=Wheatley |first2=Rick |title=Hunting For Food: Guide to Harvesting, Field Dressing and Cooking Wild Game |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3XN6CgAAQBAJ |year=2015 |publisher=F+W Media |isbn=978-1-4403-3856-4 |pages=6–77}} Chapters on hunting deer, wild hog (boar), rabbit, and squirrel.</ref>
Thousands of plant species are cultivated for aesthetic purposes as well as to provide shade, modify temperatures, reduce wind, abate noise, provide privacy, and prevent soil erosion. Plants are the basis of a multibillion-dollar per year tourism industry, which includes travel to [[garden tourism|historic gardens]], [[national park]]s, [[rainforest]]s, [[forest]]s with colorful autumn leaves, and festivals such as [[Hanami|Japan's]]<ref>{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=T2blg2Kw_zcC&pg=PA12&dq=hanami#v=onepage&q=hanami&f=false |page=12 |title=Introduction to Japanese culture |first=Daniel |last=Sosnoski |publisher=Tuttle |year=1996 |isbn=978-0-8048-2056-1}}</ref> and [[National Cherry Blossom Festival|America's cherry blossom festivals]].<ref name="NCBF">{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314055554/http://www.nationalcherryblossomfestival.org/about/history/ |archivedate=14 March 2016 |url=http://www.nationalcherryblossomfestival.org/about/history/ |title=History of the Cherry Blossom Trees and Festival |work=National Cherry Blossom Festival: About |publisher=National Cherry Blossom Festival |accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> While some [[garden]]s are planted with food crops, many are planted for aesthetic, ornamental, or conservation purposes. [[Arboretum]]s and [[botanical garden]]s are public collections of living plants. In private outdoor gardens, lawn grasses, shade trees, ornamental trees, shrubs, vines, herbaceous perennials and bedding plants are used. Gardens may cultivate the plants in a naturalistic state, or may sculpture their growth, as with [[topiary]] or [[espalier]]. [[Gardening]] is the most popular leisure activity in the U.S., and working with plants or [[horticulture therapy]] is beneficial for rehabilitating people with disabilities. Plants may also be grown or kept indoors as [[houseplant]]s, or in specialized buildings such as [[greenhouse]]s that are designed for the care and cultivation of living plants. [[Venus Flytrap]], [[sensitive plant]] and [[resurrection plant]] are examples of plants sold as novelties. There are also art forms specializing in the arrangement of cut or living plant, such as [[bonsai]], [[ikebana]], and the arrangement of cut or dried flowers. [[Ornamental plant]]s have sometimes changed the course of history, as in [[tulip mania|tulipomania]].<ref name="Lambert">{{cite web|last1=Lambert|first1=Tim|title=A Brief History of Gardening|url=http://www.localhistories.org/gardening.html|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=21 June 2016|date=2014}}</ref>
==Symbolic uses==
===In art=== {{further|Animal painting}}
Both animals and plants are significant in art, whether as background or as main subjects.
Animals, often mammals but including fish and insects among other groups, have been the [[Animal painting|subjects of art]] from the earliest times, in both early history as in [[Ancient Egypt]], and prehistory, as in the [[Lascaux|cave paintings at Lascaux]] and other sites in the [[Dordogne]], France and elsewhere. Major artistic depictions of animals include [[Albrecht Dürer]]'s 1515 ''[[Dürer's Rhinoceros|The Rhinoceros]]'', and [[George Stubbs]]'s c. 1762 horse portrait ''[[Whistlejacket]]''.<ref name="Jones">{{cite news |last1=Jones |first1=Jonathan |title=The top 10 animal portraits in art |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2014/jun/27/top-10-animal-portraits-in-art |accessdate=24 June 2016 |agency=[[The Guardian]] |date=27 June 2014}}</ref>
Plants appear in art, either to illustrate their botanical appearance,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Antheunisse |first1=Max |title=About |url=http://www.plantillustrations.org/about.php |publisher=Plant Illustrations |accessdate=20 June 2016 |date=2009}}</ref> or for the purposes of the artist, which may include decoration or religious symbolism. For example, the [[Virgin Mary]] was compared by the [[Venerable Bede]] to a [[lily]], the white [[petal]]s denoting purity of body, while the yellow [[anther]]s signified the radiant light of the soul; accordingly, European portraits of the Virgin's [[Annunciation]] may depict a vase of white lilies in her room to indicate her attributes. Plants are also often used as backgrounds or features in portraits, and as main subjects in [[still life]]s.<ref>{{cite web |title=Botanical Imagery in European Painting |publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Raymond |first1=Francine |title=Why botanical art is still blooming today |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gardening/plants/9924556/Why-botanical-art-is-still-blooming-today.html |accessdate=19 June 2016 |agency=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=12 March 2013}}</ref>
<gallery> File:Lascaux painting.jpg|[[Upper Paleolithic]] [[cave painting]] of [[aurochs]], [[horse]]s and [[deer]], [[Lascaux]], c. 17,300 years old File:Vincent Willem van Gogh 113.jpg|One of [[Vincent van Gogh]]'s ''[[Flowering Orchards]]'' paintings: ''Souvenir de Mauve'', 1888 </gallery>
===In literature and film=== [[File:Illustration at p. 73 in Just So Stories (c1912).png|thumb|"How the elephant got his trunk" in [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s ''[[Just So Stories]]'', 1902. Below the main image, a parade of animals go two by two into [[Noah's ark]].]]
Both animals and plants appear in literature and film.
Animals as varied as bees, beetles, [[List of fictional rodents|mice]], [[Foxes in popular culture|foxes]], crocodiles and [[cultural depictions of elephants|elephants]] play a wide variety of roles in literature and film.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Paterson |first1=Jennifer |title=Animals in Film and Media ''[[The Deadly Mantis]]''.<ref name="GregersdotterHöglund2016">{{cite book |last1=Gregersdotter |first1=Katarina |last2=Höglund |first2=Johan |last3=Hållén |first3=Nicklas |title=Animal Horror Cinema: Genre, History and Criticism |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hV-hCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA147 |date=2016 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-1-137-49639-3 |page=147}}</ref><ref name="WarrenThomas2009">{{cite book |last1=Warren |first1=Bill |last2=Thomas|first2=Bill |title=Keep Watching the Skies!: American Science Fiction Movies of the Fifties, The 21st Century Edition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B7kUCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT32 |date=2009 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=978-1-4766-2505-8 |page=32}}</ref><ref name="Crouse2008">{{cite book|last=Crouse |first=Richard |title=Son of the 100 Best Movies You've Never Seen |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B5alnowvF3sC&pg=PT200 |year=2008 |publisher=ECW Press|isbn=978-1-55490-330-6 |page=200}}</ref> Birds have occasionally featured in film, as in [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s 1963 ''[[The Birds (film)|The Birds]]'', loosely based on [[Daphne du Maurier]]'s [[The Birds (story)|story of the same name]], which tells the tale of sudden attacks on people by violent flocks of birds.<ref>{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=David |authorlink=David Thomson (film critic) |title='Have You Seen ... ?' A Personal introduction to 1,000 Films |year=2008 |publisher=Knopf |isbn=978-0-375-71134-3 |page=97}}</ref> [[Ken Loach]]'s admired<ref name=BFI/> 1969 ''[[Kes (film)|Kes]]'', based on [[Barry Hines]]'s 1968 novel ''[[A Kestrel for a Knave]]'', tells a story of a boy coming of age by training a [[kestrel]].<ref name=BFI>{{cite web |title=Kes (1969) |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b6adf17e2 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> [[Parasitoid]]s have inspired [[science fiction]] authors and screenwriters to create disgusting and terrifying parasitic alien species that kill their human hosts,<ref name=Moisseeff2014>{{cite web|last1=Moisseeff|first1=Marika|title=Aliens as an Invasive Reproductive Power in Science Fiction|pages=239–257|url=https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00935705|website=HAL Archives-Ouvertes|date=23 January 2014|publisher=Polis, Sofia}}</ref> such as in [[Ridley Scott]]'s 1979 film ''[[Alien (film)|Alien]]''.<ref name="Pappas2012">{{cite web |last1=Pappas |first1=Stephanie |title=5 Alien Parasites and Their Real-World Counterparts |url=https://www.livescience.com/20624-5-alien-parasites-real-inspiration.html |publisher=Live Science |date=29 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Williams |first1=Robyn |last2=Field |first2=Scott |title=Behaviour, Evolutionary Games and .... Aliens |url=http://www.abc.net.au/science/kelvin/files/s223.htm |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=30 November 2017 |date=27 September 1997}}</ref>
Plants too, both real and invented, play many roles in [[List of fictional plants|literature and film]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Literary Plants |journal=Nature Plants |date=2015 |volume=1 |issue=11 |page=15181 |url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nplants2015181 |doi=10.1038/nplants.2015.181|pmid=27251545 }}</ref> Plants' roles may be evil, as with the [[triffids]], carnivorous plants with a whip-like poisonous sting as well as mobility provided by three foot-like appendages, from [[John Wyndham]]'s 1951 [[science fiction]] novel ''[[The Day of the Triffids]]'', and subsequent adaptations for film and radio.<ref name="TelegraphFilms">{{cite news |title=Top 10: evil plants from films |accessdate=19 June 2016 |agency=The Daily Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gardening/gardeningpicturegalleries/9954137/Top-10-evil-plants-from-films.html?frame=2519788}}</ref> [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s fictional world [[Middle-earth]] features [[List of Middle-earth plants|many named kinds of plant]], including the healing herb ''athelas''<ref name="FF">[[J. R. R. Tolkien|Tolkien, J. R. R.]] (1954) ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'', I 12 "Flight to the Ford".</ref> the yellow star-flower ''elanor'' which grows in special places such as Cerin Amroth in [[Lothlórien]],<ref name="L">[[J. R. R. Tolkien|Tolkien, J. R. R.]] (1954) ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'', II 6 "Lothlórien".</ref> and the tall ''mallorn'' tree<ref name="GH">[[J. R. R. Tolkien|Tolkien, J. R. R.]] (1954) ''[[The Return of the King]]'', VI 9 "The Grey Havens".</ref> of the elves. Tolkien names several individual trees of significance in the narrative, including the Party Tree in the [[Shire]] with its happy associations,<ref name="GH"/> and the malevolent [[Old Man Willow]]<ref>[[J. R. R. Tolkien|Tolkien, J. R. R.]] (1954) ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'', I 6 "The Old Forest".</ref> in the [[Old Forest]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hazell |first1=Dinah |title=The Plants of Middle-Earth: Botany and Sub-Creation |date=2007 |publisher=Kent State University Press |page=73 |isbn=978-0-87338-883-2 |quote=That would be frightening enough in a normal forest, but the Old Forest's trees have mobility and intelligence and are directed by a malevolent force, centered in Old Man Willow}}</ref> Trees feature in many of [[Ursula K. Le Guin]]'s books, including the forest world of [[Athshe]] and the [[Immanent Grove]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Le Guin |first=Ursula K. |title=Tales from Earthsea |publisher=Harcourt |year=2001 |page=59 |isbn=978-0-15-100561-1}}</ref> on [[Islands of Earthsea|Roke]] in the [[Earthsea (book series)|Earthsea series]], to such an extent that in her introduction to her collection ''[[The Wind's Twelve Quarters]]'', she admits to "a certain obsession with trees" and describes herself as "the most [[arboreal]] science fiction writer".<ref name="Freedman2008">{{cite book |last=Freedman |first=Carl Howard |title=Conversations with Ursula K. Le Guin |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XJHVjH2hz50C&pg=PA13 |year=2008 |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |isbn=978-1-60473-094-4 |pages=12–13}}</ref> [[James Cameron]]'s 2009 film ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' features a giant tree named Hometree, the sacred gathering place of the [[humanoid]] [[Pandoran biosphere#Naʼvi|Na'vi]] tribe; the interconnected tree, tribe and planet are threatened by mining: the tribe and the film's hero fight to save them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxscreenings.com/media/pdf/JamesCameronAVATAR.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q2mqY36B?url=http://www.foxscreenings.com/media/pdf/JamesCameronAVATAR.pdf |archivedate=27 May 2010 |title=Avatar |page=25 |accessdate=9 February 2010 |last=Cameron |first=James |work=Avatar Screenings |publisher=Fox and its Related Entities |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Trees are common subjects in [[poetry]], including [[Joyce Kilmer]]'s 1913 lyric poem named "[[Trees (poem)|Trees]]".<ref>{{cite web |title=Poetry |url=http://spiritoftrees.org/poetry |website=Spirit of Trees|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Tree Poems |url=http://www.poemhunter.com/poems/tree/ |website=Poem Hunter |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> Flowers, similarly, are the subjects of many poems by poets such as [[William Blake]], [[Robert Frost]], and [[Rabindranath Tagore]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Flower Poems|url=http://www.poemhunter.com/poems/flower/|website=Poem Hunter|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref>
The [[bacterium|bacterial]] [[disease]] [[tuberculosis]] [[Tuberculosis in human culture|played a role in culture]], associated for some reason with artistic creativity. It was known as "the romantic disease".<ref name=Lawlor2006>{{cite book |last=Lawlor |first=C. |title=Consumption and Literature: The Making of the Romantic Disease |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V3eIDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA215 |year=2006 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=978-0-230-62574-7 |page=215}}</ref> Many artistic figures including the poet [[John Keats]], the composer [[Frederic Chopin]] and the artist [[Edvard Munch]] either had the disease or were close to others who did. Tuberculosis played prominent and recurring roles in diverse fields. These included [[literature]], as in [[Thomas Mann]]'s ''[[The Magic Mountain]]'', set in a [[sanatorium]]; in [[music]], as in [[Van Morrison]]'s song "[[T.B. Sheets]]"; in [[opera]], as in [[Giacomo Puccini|Puccini]]'s ''[[La bohème]]'' and [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s ''[[La Traviata]]''; in [[art]], as in [[Claude Monet|Monet]]'s painting of his first wife Camille on her deathbed; and in [[film]], such as the 1945 ''[[The Bells of St. Mary's]]'' starring [[Ingrid Bergman]] as a nun with tuberculosis.<ref name=Lemlein1981>{{cite journal|last1=Lemlein |first1=Rhoda F. |title=Influence Of Tuberculosis On The Work Of Visual Artists: Several Prominent Examples |journal=Leonardo |date=1981 |volume=14 |issue=2 |pages=114–11 |jstor=1574402}}</ref><ref name=Wilsey>{{cite web |author=Wilsey, Ashley M. |title='Half in Love with Easeful Death:' Tuberculosis in Literature |date=May 2012 |publisher=Humanities Capstone Projects (PhD Thesis), Pacific University |ref=Paper 11 |url=http://commons.pacificu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1010&context=cashu}}</ref><ref name=Morens2002/><ref name="Morens2002">{{cite journal |last1=Morens |first1=David M. |title=At the Deathbed of Consumptive Art |journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases |date=November 2002 |volume=8 |issue=11 |pages=1353–1358 |doi=10.3201/eid0811.020549 |pmid=12463180 |pmc=2738548 |url=https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/8/11/02-0549_article}}</ref><ref name=McMasterUni>{{cite web |url=http://hsl.mcmaster.libguides.com/c.php?g=306775&p=2045587 |title=Pulmonary Tuberculosis/In Literature and Art| publisher=McMaster University History of Diseases |accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=USAID>{{cite web |title=Tuberculosis Throughout History: The Arts|url=https://www.usaid.gov/sites/default/files/documents/1864/art_poster.pdf |publisher=USAID |accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref>
===In mythology and religion=== [[File:Sri Mariamman Temple Singapore amk.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35<!--width for low image-->|Animals are important in religions such as [[Hinduism]]. Here, cattle listen to [[Krishna]]'s music.]]
Animals including many [[Insects in mythology|insects]]<ref name=Hearn/> and mammals<ref name=TFL/> feature in mythology and religion; indeed, animals and plants appear in what has been suggested to be the world's first religion in the [[Paleolithic]] era.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Conklin |first1=Edward D. |title=The First Religion: Evidence for its Beginning and Earliest Artistic Expressions |date=July 2002 |publisher=University of South Australia (Ph.D. thesis) |url=http://search.ror.unisa.edu.au/media/researcharchive/open/9915960069801831/53112317960001831 |accessdate=12 September 2018 |quote=I will argue that the images of animals, plants, and hand prints were drawn primarily by women as a result of the perceptual processes of animism, anthropomorphism, dream imagery, and the analogically reasoned gynocentric view that the interior of the earth was the female-like greater origin of life.}}</ref> Among the insects, in both Japan and Europe, as far back as ancient Greece and Rome, a [[butterfly]] was seen as the personification of a person's soul, both while they were alive and after their death.<ref name=Hearn>{{cite book | last=Hearn | first=Lafcadio | authorlink=Lafcadio Hearn | year=1904 | title=Kwaidan: Stories and Studies of Strange Things | titlelink=Kwaidan: Stories and Studies of Strange Things | publisher=Dover | isbn=978-0-486-21901-1}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=did;cc=did;rgn=main;view=text;idno=did2222.0001.694 | title=Butterfly |journal=Encyclopedia of Diderot and d'Alembert | accessdate=10 July 2016| date=January 2011 | last1=Louis | first1=Chevalier de Jaucourt (Biography) }}</ref><ref>Hutchins, M., Arthur V. Evans, Rosser W. Garrison and Neil Schlager (Eds) (2003) Grzimek's Animal Life Encyclopedia, 2nd edition. Volume 3, Insects. Gale, 2003.</ref> The [[Scarab (artifact)|scarab beetle]] was sacred in ancient Egypt,<ref>{{cite book |author=Ben-Tor, Daphna |title=Scarabs, A Reflection of Ancient Egypt |location=Jerusalem |publisher= |date=1989 |isbn=978-965-278-083-6 |page=8}}</ref> while the [[praying mantis]] was considered a god in southern African [[Khoi]] and [[Bushmen|San]] tradition for its praying posture.<ref>{{cite web |title=Insek-kaleidoskoop: Die 'skynheilige' hottentotsgot |url=http://www.mieliestronk.com/insek7hotten.html |website=Mieliestronk.com |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> Among the mammals, [[Cattle in religion and mythology|cattle]],<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Biswas|first1=Soutik|title=Why the humble cow is India's most polarising animal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-34513185|publisher=BBC|accessdate=9 July 2016|work=BBC News|date=2015-10-15}}</ref> [[Deer in mythology|deer]],<ref name=TFL>{{cite web |title=Deer |url=http://treesforlife.org.uk/forest/mythology-folklore/deer/ |publisher=[[Trees for Life (Scotland)|Trees for Life]] |accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref> [[Horse worship|horses]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Hayagrīva: The Mantrayānic Aspect of Horse-cult in China and Japan |publisher=Brill Archive |page=9 |author=Robert Hans van Gulik}}</ref> [[Cultural depictions of lions|lions]]<ref>{{cite web |last1=Grainger |first1=Richard |title=Lion Depiction across Ancient and Modern Religions |url=https://lionalert.org/page/Lion_Depiction_Across_Ancient_and_Modern_Religions |publisher=ALERT |accessdate=6 July 2016 |date=24 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923134807/https://lionalert.org/page/Lion_Depiction_Across_Ancient_and_Modern_Religions |archivedate=23 September 2016 |df= }}</ref> and [[Wolves in folklore, religion and mythology|wolves]] (and [[werewolf|werewolves]]),<ref>{{cite book |author=McCone, Kim R. |title=Hund, Wolf, und Krieger bei den Indogermanen |editor=Meid, W. |work=Studien zum indogermanischen Wortschatz |publisher= |location=Innsbruck |date=1987 |pages=101–154}}</ref> are the subjects of myths and worship. Of the twelve [[signs of the zodiac|signs of the Western zodiac]], six—[[Aries (astrology)|Aries]] ([[Sheep|ram]]), [[Taurus (astrology)|Taurus]] ([[bull]]), [[Cancer (astrology)|Cancer]] ([[crab]]), [[Leo (astrology)|Leo]] ([[lion]]), [[Scorpio (astrology)|Scorpio]] ([[scorpion]]), and [[Pisces (astrology)|Pisces]] ([[fish]])—are animals, while two others, [[Sagittarius (astrology)|Sagittarius]] (horse/man) and [[Capricorn (astrology)|Capricorn]] (fish/goat) are hybrid animals; the name ''zodiac'' indeed means a circle of animals. All twelve signs of the [[Chinese zodiac]] are animals.<ref>Lau, Theodora, ''The Handbook of Chinese Horoscopes'', pp. 2–8, 30–5, 60–4, 88–94, 118–24, 148–53, 178–84, 208–13, 238–44, 270–78, 306–12, 338–44, Souvenir Press, New York, 2005</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=he Zodiac and the Ecliptic|publisher=Western Washington University}}</ref><ref name="Tester1987">{{cite book|last=Tester|first=S. Jim|title=A History of Western Astrology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L0HSvH96alIC&pg=PA31|year=1987|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|isbn=978-0-85115-446-6|pages=31–33 and passim}}</ref>
Plants including [[Trees in mythology|trees]] are important in mythology and religion, where they symbolise themes such as [[fertility]], growth, [[immortality]] and [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|rebirth]], and may be more or less magical.<ref>{{cite web |title=Plants in Mythology |url=http://www.mythencyclopedia.com/Pa-Pr/Plants-in-Mythology.html |publisher=Myth Encyclopedia |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Leitten |first1=Rebecca Rose |title=Plant Myths and Legends |url=http://bhort.bh.cornell.edu/conservatory/cpage3.html |publisher=Cornell University Liberty Hyde Bailey Conservatory |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> Thus in [[Latvian mythology]], [[Austras koks]] is a tree which grows from the start of the Sun's daily journey across the sky.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ķencis |first=Toms |title=The Latvian Mythological space in scholarly Time |journal=Archaeologia Baltica |issue=15 |pages=144 |year=2011 |url=http://www.ku.lt/leidykla/leidiniai/Archaeologia_BALTICA/Archaeologia_BALTICA_15.pdf |accessdate=21 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325025627/http://www.ku.lt/leidykla/leidiniai/Archaeologia_BALTICA/Archaeologia_BALTICA_15.pdf |archivedate=25 March 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia| last=Vīķe-Freiberga |first=Vaira |authorlink=Vaira Vīķe-Freiberga| editor-last=Jones | editor-first=Lindsay | title =Saule | encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Religion | volume=12 | pages=8131–8135 | publisher =Thomson Gale| year=2005|edition=2nd}}</ref> A different cosmic tree is [[Yggdrasil]], the [[World tree]] of [[Norse mythology]], on which [[Odin]] hung.<ref>{{cite book |last=Dronke |first=Ursula |authorlink=Ursula Dronke |author-mask=[[Ursula Dronke|Dronke, Ursula]] (Trans.) |year=1997 |title=The Poetic Edda: Volume II: Mythological Poems |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=978-0-19-811181-8 |page=7}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Davidson |first=Hilda Ellis |authorlink=Hilda Ellis Davidson |title=The Lost Beliefs of Northern Europe |publisher=[[Routledge]] |year=1993 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=sWLVZN0H224C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-0-203-40850-6 |page=69}}</ref> Different again is the barnacle tree, believed in the [[Middle Ages]] to have barnacles that opened to reveal [[Barnacle goose|geese]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Barnacle Goose |url=http://bestiary.ca/beasts/beast1195.htm |publisher=The Medieval Bestiary |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> a story which may perhaps have started from an observation of [[goose barnacle]]s growing on [[driftwood]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Beatrice White |year=1945 |title=Whale-hunting, the barnacle goose, and the date of the "Ancrene Riwle". Three notes on Old and Middle English |journal=[[The Modern Language Review]] |volume=40 |issue=3 |pages=205–207 |jstor=3716844}}</ref> [[Greek mythology]] mentions many plants and flowers,<ref>{{cite web |title=Flora 1: Plants of Greek Myth |url=http://www.theoi.com/Flora1.html |publisher=Theoi |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> where for example the [[lotus tree]] bears a fruit that causes a pleasant drowsiness,<ref>{{cite book |work=Dictionary of Phrase and Fable |title=Lotus tree |page=526 |author=Brewer, Ebenezer Cobham}}</ref> while [[Moly (herb)|moly]] is a magic herb mentioned by [[Homer]] in the ''[[Odyssey]]'' with a black root and white blossoms.<ref>{{EB1911 |noprescript=1 |wstitle=Moly |volume=18 |page=681}} cites: Homer, ''Odyssey'', x. 302–306.</ref> Magic plants are found, too, in [[Serbian mythology]], where the [[raskovnik]] is supposed to be able to open any [[Lock (security device)|lock]].<ref name="Stoynev">{{cite book |last=Стойнев |first=Анани |author2=Димитър Попов |author3=Маргарита Василева |author4=Рачко Попов |title=Българска митология. Енциклопедичен речник |year=2006 |publisher=изд. Захари Стоянов |language=Bulgarian |isbn=978-954-739-682-1 |page=165 |chapter=Костенурка}}</ref><ref name="Stareva">{{cite book |last=Старева |first=Лилия |title=Български магии и гадания |year=2007 |publisher=Труд |isbn=978-954-528-772-5 |pages=243–244 |language=Bulgarian}}</ref><!--<ref name="Radenkovic">{{cite web |url=http://kapija.narod.ru/Ethnoslavistics/rad_raskovnik.htm |script-title=sr:Расковник у кругу сличних биљака |last=Раденковић |first=Љубинко |date=2000–2001 |publisher=Slavic Gate |language=Russian |accessdate=24 August 2010}}</ref>--> In [[Buddhist symbolism]], both the [[Nelumbo nucifera|lotus]] and the [[Bodhi Tree]] are significant. The lotus is one of the [[Ashtamangala]] (eight auspicious signs) shared between [[Buddhism]], [[Jainism]] and [[Hinduism]], representing the primordial purity of [[Three Vajras|body, speech, and mind]], floating above the muddy waters of [[Upādāna|attachment]] and desire.<ref name="AndersonPearsall2012">{{cite book |last1=Anderson |first1=E.N. |last2=Pearsall |first2=Deborah |last3=Hunn |first3=Eugene |first4=Nancy |last4=Turner |title=Ethnobiology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MIfevntk-mEC&pg=PT602 |year=2012 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |isbn=978-1-118-01586-5 |page=602}}</ref> The Bodhi Tree is the [[sacred fig]] tree under which the Buddha is said to have attained enlightenment; the name is also given to other Bodhi trees thought to have been propagated from the original tree.<ref name="gethin">{{cite book |last=Gethin |first=Rupert |authorlink=Rupert Gethin |title=The Foundations of Buddhism |page=22 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=1998 |isbn=978-0-19-289223-2}}</ref>

= |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1982|04|18|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[Riyadh]], [[Saudi Arabia]] |death_date = {{Death year and age|2017|1982}} |death_place = [[Yemen]] |death_cause = [[Drone strike]] |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |residence = |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = [[Saudi Arabia]] |other_names = *Abu Saleh *Khalid Ibrahim Al Aseery *Khaled Ibrahim Ahmad Al-Sunbul Al-Assiri |known_for = [[al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] bomb-maker |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = [[Riyadh]] |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = [[Abdullah al-Asiri]] (younger brother) |callsign = |awards = |signature = |website = |footnotes = |box_width = }} '''Ibrahim Hassan Tali al-Asiri''' (April 18, 1982–2017) was a citizen of [[Saudi Arabia]] suspected of being chief bomb-maker of [[al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]].<ref name=SaudiGazette2009-08-31>{{cite news |url = http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2009083148387 |title = Suicide bomber named |date = September 1, 2009 |author = Abdullah Al-Oreifij |publisher = [[Saudi Gazette]] |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.saudigazette.com.sa%2Findex.cfm%3Fmethod%3Dhome.regcon%26contentID%3D2009083148387&date=2009-09-01 |archivedate = September 1, 2009 |accessdate = August 2, 2009 |deadurl = yes}}</ref> He was reported to have been responsible for making the bombs used by his brother [[Abdullah al-Asiri]] in his suicide bombing, the [[2009 Christmas Day bomb plot]], the [[2010 cargo plane bomb plot]], and the [[May 8th 2012 Terror Plot]].<ref name=DailyBeast2012-05-14>{{cite news |url = http://www.thedailybeast.com//content/newsweek/2012/05/13/al-qaeda-s-body-bombs-al-asiri-s-next-threat.html |title = Ibrahim al-Asiri: The Body Bomb Menace |publisher = [[Daily Beast]] |date = 2012-05-14 |accessdate = 2012-05-14 |author = Daniel Klaidman, Christopher Dickey}} [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thedailybeast.com%2Fnewsweek%2F2012%2F05%2F13%2Fal-qaeda-s-body-bombs-al-asiri-s-next-threat.html&date=2012-05-14 mirror]</ref>
==History== Little is known about al-Asiri’s early life; he was born in 1982 into a religious and military family in [[Riyadh]] with four brothers and three sisters.<ref name=BBC>{{cite web| title=Profile: Al-Qaeda 'bomb maker' Ibrahim al-Asiri | author=BBC News| publisher=BBC News| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11662143| date=9 May 2012}}</ref> Al-Asiri's father is a retired soldier. As of September 2009, he had two surviving brothers.<ref name=SaudiGazette2009-08-31/>
The ''[[Saudi Gazette]]'' reported that al-Asiri had been imprisoned and released. His imprisonment was a result of an attempt to enter [[Iraq]] to join Islamist insurgents.<ref name=BBC /> He reportedly left Saudi Arabia for [[Yemen]] together with his brother [[Abdullah al-Asiri]] — whom he had recruited to al-Qaeda — to join up with al-Qaeda members.<ref name=SaudiGazette2009-08-31/>
On February 3, 2009, al-Asiri and Abdullah were named on a [[Saudi list of most wanted suspected terrorists|list of Saudi Arabia's most wanted terrorist suspects]].<ref name=ArabNews2009-02-03>{{cite news |url = http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1&section=0&article=118850&d=3&m=2&y=2009 |title = Kingdom unveils list of 85 wanted militants abroad |date = February 3, 2009 |publisher = [[Arab News]] |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.arabnews.com%2F%3Fpage%3D1%26section%3D0%26article%3D118850%26d%3D3%26m%3D2%26y%3D2009&date=2009-09-10 |archivedate = September 10, 2009 |deadurl = yes}}</ref><ref name=SaudiGazetteSaudiMostWanted2009-02-03>{{cite news |url = http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2009020328293 |title = 85 on Saudi wanted list of militants |publisher = [[Saudi Gazette]] |date = February 3, 2009 |accessdate = February 3, 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.saudigazette.com.sa%2Findex.cfm%3Fmethod%3Dhome.regcon%26contentID%3D2009020328293&date=2009-02-04 |archivedate = February 4, 2009 |deadurl = yes}}</ref><ref name=MiamiHerald2009-02-02>{{cite news |url = http://www.miamiherald.com/news/world/story/884630.html |title = Saudi 'most wanted list' includes freed Guantánamo detainees |publisher = [[Miami Herald]] |author = Carol Rosenberg |date = February 2, 2009 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.miamiherald.com%2Fnews%2Fworld%2Fstory%2F884630.html&date=2009-02-03 |archivedate = February 3, 2009 |deadurl = yes}}</ref> The list published by the Government of Saudi Arabia listed 85 individuals, 83 of whom were Saudis, and 2 were from Yemen.
On August 27, 2009, Abdullah blew himself up at the [[Jeddah]] palace of Saudi Arabia's Deputy Minister of the Interior prince [[Mohammed bin Nayef]], in attempt to assassinate him after posing as a repentant militant.<ref name=SaudiGazette2009-08-31/><ref name=Reuters2009-08-30>{{cite news |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSLU594154 |title = Saudi prince defends policy on militants |date = August 30, 2009 |publisher = Reuters |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.reuters.com%2Farticle%2FlatestCrisis%2FidUSLU594154&date=2009-09-01 |archivedate = September 1, 2009 |first = Andrew |last = Hammond |deadurl = yes }}</ref><ref name=MetroUS2009-08-30>{{cite news |url = http://www.metro.us/us/article/2009/08/31/03/2946-82/index.xml |title = Bizarre tale of Saudi bomber: Al-Qaida terrorist rode victim’s private jet |date = August 30, 2009 |publisher = [[Metro US]] |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.metro.us%2Fus%2Farticle%2F2009%2F08%2F31%2F03%2F2946-82%2Findex.xml&date=2009-09-01 |archivedate = September 1, 2009 |deadurl = yes}}</ref> Abdullah, who had been recruited by Ibrahim as a [[suicide bomber]], used a [[pentaerythritol tetranitrate]] (PETN) bomb that his brother had hidden in his [[rectum]]. Abdullah died in the attempt, but bin Nayef survived with minor injuries.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/10/20101031144429122829.html |title=Passenger jets carried Dubai bomb |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=October 31, 2010|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/11/01/world/main7010288.shtml |title=Saudi Bombmaker Key Suspect in Yemen Plot |agency=Associated Press | publisher = CBS News | date= 1 November 2010|accessdate=12 March 2014}}</ref>
==Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula==
al-Asiri is suspected of being the main explosives expert for [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] (AQAP) and the bomb-maker responsible for building the bombs in the [[2010 cargo plane bomb plot]].<ref name="guardian">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/oct/31/cargo-bombs-plot-us-saudi-extremist | title=Cargo bombs plot: US hunts Saudi extremist|accessdate=October 31, 2010|date=October 31, 2010|publisher=The Guardian|last1=McGreal|first1= Chris|last2=Dodd|first2=Vikram |location=London}}</ref> He is a likely suspect due to his history of creating explosive devices using [[PETN]], including his involvement in the failed [[Northwest Airlines Flight 253|Christmas Day bomb plot]].<ref name="telegraph2">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/8102883/Al-Qaeda-plot-flight-ban-on-freight-from-Somalia.html|title=Al-Qaeda plot: Flight ban on freight from Somalia |publisher=Telegraph |date=November 1, 2010 |accessdate=November 1, 2010 |location=London}}</ref> Evidence suggested the same person constructed both the Yemen parcel bombs and the device worn by [[Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab]], the Nigerian who attempted to ignite the Christmas Day bomb on a plane in 2009. One of the detonators was nearly identical to the one used in the Christmas Day attack.<ref>{{cite news|author=Frank Gardner |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11663381 |title= Saudi man 'key suspect' in jet bomb plot, says US |publisher=BBC News|date=November 1, 2010 |accessdate=November 1, 2010}}</ref>
In May 2012, American security officials leaked their acquisition of a document describing how to prepare and use liquid explosive implants ([[surgically implanted explosive device]]s).<ref name="DailyBeast2012-05-14" /><ref name=Boing2012-05-14>{{cite news |url = http://boingboing.net/2012/05/14/youre-the-bomb-surgically.html |title = You da bomb! (surgically-implanted explosives) |publisher = [[Boing boing]] |date = 2012-05-14 |accessdate = 2012-05-14 |author = David Pescovitz |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fboingboing.net%2F2012%2F05%2F14%2Fyoure-the-bomb-surgically.html&date=2012-05-14 |archivedate = 2012-05-14}}</ref><ref name=IBTimes-2012-05-14>{{cite news |url = http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/340801/20120514/al-qaida-s-body-bombs-increase-fears.htm |title = Al-Qaida’s ‘Body Bombs’ increase Fears of Global Attacks by Master Bomb-Maker Ibrahim Hassan Tali al-Asiri |publisher = [[International Business Times]] |date = 2012-05-14 |accessdate = 2012-05-14 |author = Anissa Haddadi |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ibtimes.co.uk%2Farticles%2F340801%2F20120514%2Fal-qaida-s-body-bombs-increase-fears.htm&date=2012-05-14 |archivedate = 2012-05-14}}</ref><ref name=TheMirror2012-05-14>{{cite news |url = https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/doctors-trained-to-plant-explosives-inside-832010 |title = Breast bombers: Doctors trained to plant explosives inside chest of female suicide bombers |publisher = [[The Daily Mirror]] |date = 2012-05-14 |accessdate = 2012-05-14 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mirror.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworld-news%2Fdoctors-trained-to-plant-explosives-inside-832010&date=2012-05-14 |archivedate = 2012-05-14}}</ref> The implants would contain no metal parts, making them virtually undetectable by x-rays. Al-Asiri was reported to have been responsible for the development of the new weapon.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
===Reports of death===
In September 2011, al-Asiri was reported to have possibly been killed by a [[drone strike]] together with other AQAP suspects, including American-Yemeni cleric [[Anwar al-Awlaki]].<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/09/30/national/main20114215.shtml?tag=contentBody;storyMediaBox Top al Qaeda bombmaker dead in drone strike], CBS News, September 30, 2011</ref> A Yemeni official denied that al-Asiri was killed.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/official-al-qaida-in-yemen-bomb-maker-not-killed-in-al-awlaki-strike/2011/10/02/gIQAPDakFL_story.html Official: Al-Qaida in Yemen bomb maker not killed in Al-Awlaki strike], Associated Press in ''Washington Post'', October 2, 2011</ref> On August 13, 2013, it was reported that Al-Asiri may have been seriously wounded by a drone strike which occurred on August 10.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/08/13/20009098-reports-al-qaedas-master-bombmaker-wounded-in-us-drone-strike?lite|author=Jim Miklaszewski, Courtney Kube and Richard Esposito|title=Reports:Al-Qaeda's Master Bombmaker Wounded In US Drone Strike|publisher=NBC News|date=August 13, 2013|accessdate=August 13, 2013}}</ref> A Yemeni official denied that al-Asiri was wounded.<ref>https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2013/08/yemeni_official_denies_report.php</ref> Al-Asiri was thought to have possibly been killed in a fire fight on April 20, 2014. Yemeni troops recovered bodies to run DNA tests, but the tests were not a match.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2014/04/22/world/meast/yemen-terror-operation-dna/index.html?hpt=wo_c2 Was al Qaeda bomb chief killed in Yemen?], Mohammed Jamjoom and Barbara Starr, CNN, April 22, 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2014/04/28/world/meast/yemen-dna-al-qaeda/index.html?hpt=wo_c2 DNA test: Remains from airstrike in Yemen not those of al Qaeda bomb-maker], Paul Cruickshank, Mohammed Jamjoom and Nic Robertson, CNN, April 28, 2014</ref>
Al-Asiri appeared in a 2016 video making references to Saudi Arabia's recent executions of al-Qaeda militants, thus confirming that he remained alive.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bomb-making terrorist threatens US, Saudi Arabia over executions|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/01/11/al-qaida-threatens-saudis-us-over-execution-militants.html|website=Fox News|publisher=Associated Press}}</ref>
On August 20, 2018, United States officials announced they were confident that Al-Asiri had been killed by a drone strike in late 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/ibrahim-al-asiri-chief-al-qaeda-bomb-maker-killed-in-u-s-drone-strike/|title=U.S. officials confident drone strike killed chief al Qaeda bomb maker|last=Martin|first=David|date=August 20, 2018|work=[[CBS News]]|access-date=August 21, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
===Sanctions===
On 24 March 2011, al-Asiri was added to the U.S. list of terrorists. He was wanted by the government of Saudi Arabia and was the subject of an [[Interpol]] Orange Notice.<ref>[https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2011/03/158911.htm Department of State's Terrorist Designation of Ibrahim Hassan Tali Al-Asiri], [[U.S. Department of State]], 24 March 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chi-ap-us-us-al-qaidabombma,0,621043.story US designates al-Qaida bomb maker as a terrorist], ''[[Associated Press|AP]]'', ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', 24 March 2011</ref>

{{Infobox language family |name=Kaba |altname=Sara Kaba |region=[[Central African Republic|CAR]], [[Chad]] |familycolor=Nilo-Saharan |fam2=[[Central Sudanic]] |fam3=[[Bongo–Bagirmi languages|Bongo–Bagirmi]] |child1=[[Kaba Deme language|Kaba Deme]] |child2=[[Kaba Na language|Kaba Na]] |child3=[[Kulfa language|Kulfa]] |glotto=sara1348 |glottoname={{nowrap|Sara Kaba}} |glotto2=kulf1238 |glottoname2=Kulfa }}
The '''Kaba languages''', also called ''Sara Kaba'' but not to be confused with the [[Sara languages]],<ref>The [http://morkegbooks.com/Services/World/Languages/SaraBagirmi//pdfs/SaraKabaNotSaraProper.pdf Sara Language Project], among others, argues that Sara Kaba is distinct from the Sara languages.</ref> comprise three to five languages of [[Chad]] and the [[Central African Republic]]. They are [[Bongo–Bagirmi languages]] of the [[Central Sudanic languages|Central Sudanic]] language family.
The most populous Kaba languages are [[Kaba Deme language|Kaba Deme]] and [[Kaba Na language|Kaba Naa]] (Kaba Na, Kaba Nar), spoken by about forty thousand people apiece. Others are [[Kaba language|Kaba proper]] (Ta Sara), [[Kaba Dunjo language|Kaba/Sara Dunjo]], and [[Kulfa language|Kulfa]] (Kaba So, Kurmi). It is not clear that Naa, Dunjo, and Kaba proper (Ta Sara) are actually distinct languages. Kulfa speakers are ethnically distinct.
The terms "Kaba" and "Sara" are generic and often interchangeable, and do not correspond to the somewhat arbitrarily named Kaba and Sara branches of Central Sudanic. [[Kabba language|Kabba]] and [[Laka language|Kabba Laka]], for example, are Sara languages, and many of the Kaba languages go under the names "Kaba", "Sara", and "Kaba Sara".

{{Unreferenced|date=July 2012}} [[File:Periferia Thessalias.png|thumb|350px|Map of [[Thessaly]]]] '''Karagounides''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: Καραγκούνηδες; Singular: '''Karagounis''' [[Greek language|Greek]]: Καραγκούνης) is the name of the native people of the western plains of [[Thessaly]], [[Greece]]. More specifically, the term is used to refer to the inhabitants of the lowland farming communities of the [[Karditsa (regional unit)|Karditsa]] and [[Trikala (regional unit)|Trikala]] regions, and the area around the city of [[Farsala]].
The older Karagounides still speak the [[Aeolic Greek|Aeolic dialect]] of the Greek language.

An '''LGBT liaison''' is any individual employed by an organization or institution as a [[point of contact]], serving as both a spokesperson for the organization to a local LGBT demographics as well as a representative of LGBT interests to the leaders of the organization. LGBT liaisons typically play an advisory role to organizations or government branches.
==Liaison Officers in Police Departments== '''LGBT Liaison Officers''' have been appointed since at least 1962, when [[San Francisco Police Department]] appointed [[Elliott Blackstone]] as the United States' first liaison officer to the "[[homophile]] community". A pioneer of [[community policing]], Blackstone worked within the police department to change policy and procedures directed against the LGBT community, such as [[entrapment]] of gay men in public restrooms.
==Notable LGBT liaisons== * [[Aditi Hardikar]] - Joined the White House as LGBT liaison in November 2014.<ref name="Aditi Hardikar">{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Chris|title=New White House LGBT liaison named|url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2014/11/10/new-white-house-lgbt-liaison-named/|accessdate=18 September 2015|publisher=Washington Blade|date=November 10, 2014|location=Washington, DC}}</ref> * [[Monique Dorsainvil]] - Served as White House LGBT liaison from Raghavan's resignation<ref name="Raghavan resignation">{{cite news|last1=Snow|first1=Justin|title=White House LGBT liaison to depart Obama administration|url=http://www.metroweekly.com/2014/09/white-house-lgbt-liaison-to-depart-administration/|accessdate=17 September 2015|publisher=Metro Weekly|date=September 4, 2014|location=Washington, DC}}</ref> until the position was filled by Aditi Hardikar.<ref name="Aditi Hardikar" /> * [[Gautam Raghavan]] - LGBT liaison (officially "Associate Director of Public Engagement") in the [[White House Office of Public Engagement and Intergovernmental Affairs]], appointed by the president<ref name="Raghavan resignation" /> * [[Richard Socarides]] - former White House LGBT liaison * [[Brian Bond (activist)|Brian Bond]] - former White House LGBT liaison * Detective [[Kevin Czartoryski]] - liaison officer for the [[New York Police Department]] to the LGBT community under the Deputy Commissioner for Public Information. Died in 2010 of a [[Health effects arising from the September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks-related illness]]. * [[Bill Kraus]] - gay liaison advisor to Congressman [[Phillip Burton]]. Successful in persuading Burton to publicly acknowledge the need for AIDS research * [[Connie Locke]] - [[Atlanta Police Department]]'s first LGBT liaison (appointed 2002) * [[Lawrence McKeon]] - first mayoral liaison to LGBT community in Chicago, appointed 1992 by [[Richard M. Daley]]
==Notable LGBT liaison units== * [[Gay and Lesbian Liaison Unit]] - [[Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia]] (established June 2000) * LGBT liaison team in the [[New York City Police Department Community Affairs Bureau]] * Gay and Lesbian Liaison Officers<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.police.nsw.gov.au/community_issues/gay,_lesbian_and_transgender_issues|title=Sexuality, Gender Diversity and Intersex. Working with lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex people - NSW Police Force|last=Wales|first=corporateName=NSW Police Force; jurisdiction=New South|website=www.police.nsw.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2017-03-22}}</ref> (referred to as GLLO) team in the [[New South Wales Police Force]], for over 25 years.
